summary: This is an email chain from July 2019 discussing legal strategy in the Florida CVRA case involving Jeffrey Epstein. The emails focus on a filing by Jane Doe 1 and 2 arguing that the Non-Prosecution Agreement (NPA) only covers Florida crimes, and mention a motion by Epstein's lawyer Marty Weinberg for a sur-reply. The correspondence is between legal professionals coordinating on the case.

persons.name: Marty Weinberg
persons.context: Epstein's attorney who filed a motion for a sur-reply in the Florida CVRA case, arguing for an opportunity to discuss the scope of the NPA.

persons.name: Judge Marra
persons.context: The judge presiding over the Florida CVRA case who is poised to rule rapidly on the motion for a sur-reply and asked for a quick response.

connections.description: Weinberg is identified as Epstein's lawyer, filing motions on his behalf in the Florida CVRA case.

events.title: Filing by Jane Doe 1 and 2
events.description: Jane Doe 1 and 2 filed a brief in the Florida CVRA case arguing that the NPA only covers Florida crimes and Florida victims, and that Judge Marra must craft remedies solely related to Florida.

events.title: Reply brief filed
events.description: The legal team for Jane Doe 1 and 2 filed their reply brief on remedies, which should have brought all briefing on remedies for the CVRA violation to a close.

events.title: Weinberg files motion for sur-reply
events.description: Epstein's lawyer Marty Weinberg filed a motion for a sur-reply to discuss, among other things, the scope of the NPA.

events.title: Planned opposition filing
events.description: The legal team planned to file an opposition on Monday to Weinberg extending the briefing further.

events.title: Clients told NPA did not extend to New York
events.description: The email mentions that the clients (presumably Jane Doe 1 and 2) were told back in 2013 that the NPA did not extend to New York or other jurisdictions.

keyFacts: The legal argument centers on whether the 2007 Non-Prosecution Agreement (NPA) with Jeffrey Epstein only covers Florida crimes and victims, not crimes in New York or other jurisdictions.
Epstein's lawyer Marty Weinberg filed a motion for a sur-reply to discuss the scope of the NPA, indicating ongoing legal battles over the agreement's interpretation.
Jane Doe 1 and 2's legal team argued that Judge Marra must craft remedies solely related to Florida crimes because the NPA only covers Florida.
The email reveals that victims were told in 2013 that the NPA did not extend to New York, suggesting early awareness of jurisdictional limitations.
The correspondence shows coordination between legal professionals in July 2019 as the Florida CVRA case was moving toward resolution on remedy issues.
